conclusion: Process A→B is isothermal, meaning constant temperature.
In an isothermal process for an ideal gas, ΔU = 0 because internal energy depends only on temperature.
First law of thermodynamics: ΔU = Q - W.
Since ΔU = 0 in an isothermal process, Q = W.
In process A→B, the volume of the gas increases as shown by the rightward movement along the V-axis.
The increase in volume means the gas does work on its surroundings.
To maintain constant internal energy, the gas must absorb heat to balance the work done.
The gas absorbs heat during the A→B process.
In conclusion, the gas absorbs heat when moving from state A to state B.
